subtitles.text: Hi and welcome to Mia-Platform video Pills.
In this video, we will show you the new low code capability of Mia-Platform Back Office.
Let's start.
We have already installed the Back Office application.
In fact, the sidebar shows the dedicated tab.
Click on it and take a moment to explore the section.
We reached the pages section where we can create a new page for our Back Office.
By default, an example page is created.
Next, we have the layout section where we can edit the basic properties and configurations of the theme.
We move on to the settings section, where we find the URIs error pages, Mount Point, import map and shared properties.
Next, you can see the configuration section of the web server with headers, entry points and content types.
At the end, It is the advanced configuration, which allows us to edit the code directly with the help of a preview.
To see how easy it is to manage the Back Office, let us create a new page.
Back to the pages. Click on Add new page.
Once the modal is displayed, select iFrame as the page type, decide a name and a rendering route.
Click on next, Enter the iFrame source and click Save.
The new page is now listed in the table To display the new page in the navigation bar.
Go to the layout tab.
Here, a new menu item can be added.
Go to menu items and click edit properties.
Add a new item and write the configuration.
Save.
We now have a new menu item.
Go to the advanced tab to see a running preview Save the project.
Now, deploy it.
If we navigate to the public URL, we can see the new page in the sidebar.
Let's create a new page type.
Instead of iFrame, select Compose.
Call the page “Users”.
Use “Users” also for the rendering route.
Click on next.
Here we can see that we can choose different page templates such as: blank page, page with table, calendar view, picture gallery and details page.
Each page has its own goal.
For example, a calendar page might be useful for an appointment manager.
An image gallery page might be perfect if you have to manage various media files.
Go ahead and choose the page with the table template.
Save it.
Unlike the iFrame page type, the compose page type allows you to configure several options.
Click on the button.
A preview page is opening.
Here you can adapt the page your business needs, starting with the page name or the text of the search bar up to some advanced functions.
For example, the table field.
We now connect the data collections.
In this case under connectors and adapters.
We select “/users” for the CRUD service.
Once done, add the new item to the menu.
Instead of using the low code configuration, you now use the advanced settings where you can directly add the code.
Here's the new menu item.
Save the configuration.
Now we can deploy and see the result.
Refreshing the page.
We find our page with the tables already populated with user data.
Finally, we customize our layout.
For example, we can switch the navigation layout.
Let us say that our brand is green.
Of course, we can modify our layout with a green user interface.
Thanks to this low code function, the Back Office becomes a powerful tool, highly customizable and quickly adaptable to your business needs.
In a short time, a data-rich, scalable and high performance tool can be implemented abstracting the complexity of maintenance.
